reviews.review_msg: Dr. Sedra is one of the best history professors at SFU and a very friendly person. I enjoyed his class, specifically the lectures, films, and readings, which are very intriguing. I strongly recommend taking this class.
Goated prof. Not too hard but very enjoyable class.

A very interesting class with very engaging lectures. Exams were based off of material in 5 or so lectures that weren't recorded, and we were given lots of pointers for the essay. Expectations are fair, bordering on easy. An average of 50 pages of reading were assigned per week.

Currently taking 151 with Paul this semester. He gives very clear, detailed expectations on assignment criteria. His lectures are super engaging and very interesting. He's a super smart guy, and he repeats key terms a lot to ensure students are locking in the important info. Would def recommend taking a course with Paul, pretty goated prof tbh

sedra is an amazing lecturer but be prepared to cover a lot of information very quickly! extremely knowledgable on the topic of the middle east and a respectable guy. if you take hist151 i would recommend doing some prior research as he will assume you know what he is talking about!!

textbook, get ur textbook beforehand. will literally save ur ass in this class i swear. super nice, funny, and accessible after class for any questions. TA was hot, and nice lmfao explained stuff well, participate! attendance in tutorials mattered. midterm/final was text-heavy, read beforehand. answering questions in paragraphs+ gives a word limit.
He is very excited and enthusiastic about the topic which I greatly appreciate. His tutorials are clear and it is so far and he is very friendly.

Prof Sedra is great! The midterm/final are based heavily on lectures but the text went into more detail on the stuff we would talk about in class. He doesn't post his slides but he does record his lectures! He makes the subject very clear if you have no background info on the topic. If you put in a bit of effort it's easy to get a good grade

Paul is hands down one of my favorite profs that I've had in my academic career. Super passionate, lectures are really interesting and easy to follow and I feel like I have retained a majority of what I have learned post final which does not happen often as all of you know lol. Too bad he isn't returning to SFU or else I would 100% take him again!

Amazing class, with an amazing professor. It's really too bad he's going on leave, he's very approachable and clearly very knowledgeable. I wish I could take this class again because it was so interesting!

This man is incredibly knowledgeable on the topic of middle eastern history.  The lectures in this course are like movies, so make sure to attend each one.  My only criticism is that it is somewhat difficult to take notes at the same pace that he lectures, but if you study with a friend I'm sure you'll be able to fill the gaps.

He gives great lectures and loves to discuss the material with students. Very open and friendly. He doesn't post lectures online and won't let you bring a laptop to class so you better take good notes. Exams are based on lectures. His TA's are tough markers and seem to be more strict than the professor.

A very informative class. Professor Sedra gives fantastic lectures and organizes them in an engaging way. He is especially good at presenting differing perspectives on historical events in a relatively neutral way, allowing students to form their own opinions. The readings used in this class have come in handy in subsequent courses!

Professor Sedra teaches a fantastic introduction to the Middle East. His lectures are informative, engaging and well organized. Readings compliment the lectures. The work assigned is not excessive, but it does require you to think critically.   Overall, the best lower level course I have ever taken.

Only took him for a 1st yr lecture, so TAs took care of tutorial, but an excellent professor. Eloquent, extremely insightful, and very adept at navigating difficult historical topics to present different avenues of scholarship in an engaging and graspable way - everything a survey course should actually be.

Although he is knowledgeable (on Egypt in particular), he is not the best at conveying information. His biggest weakness is that he cannot handle opinions that differ from his own - this is esp true when it comes to essay arguments. Note:  If your essay speaks to an opinion he supports, you will grade well. If not, prepare for overly harsh grading.
Amazing guy. Seems super interested in the subject of the Middle East and has a lot of knowledge. Take a class with him!

I had Sedra for HIST 151(A-) and HIST 355(B+). He's was more relaxed in my upper level and much more open to questions/comments. It's true that he is a tough grader, and doesn't offer the best feedback but you can go see him in his office hours. There is a lot of reading but I found the course content so interesting it wasn't a big deal. Great prof
Unjustifiably tough grader. TA's are horrible. Never again.

Paul Sedra is an incredibly knowledgeable professor, that could answer nearly any question that you might have about Middle East, and ANY question you have about Egypt :)  His lectures are the best structured lectures I have ever had. Pr. Sedra is always prepared and  asks thought provoking questions.  As for the grading it is fair, work  results!

Sedra is an awesome professor at SFU. One of the best in the history department. He gives thought provoking lectures and knows his material well, which makes for a very entertaining class. I wouldn't say his class is easy, but you'll likely do well if you attend class and do the assigned readings.

Great guy, very passionate about the subject, and knows his stuff.  Lectures are very detailed and it is important you take notes.  Lots of textbook readings also, and make you study anything related to Egypt, which is his favourite subject.

Awesome prof! Great at teaching, passionate about the subject, jolly and funny guy. Buy the 2 textbooks but do not buy "Diaries of an Unfinished Revolution" because he never talks about or mentions it in class and only 30 pages were assigned from it to read but none of it was ever on any exams or essays. study ahead its loaded wit info

I loved this class. Middle Eastern history is something that Dr. Sedra is extremely knowledgeable and passionate about. His lectures are sometimes overwhelming, minimal slides, lots to write down, but in my term he recorded them, which was convenient. Highly recommended if you're actually interested, but not easy.

Sedra is a good prof, speaks clearly, and writes fair exams. If you're a good writer, or willing to take the time to have a TA or Sedra himself look at a draft of your essay, then you'll do fine on the term paper. The exams seem to be based on simple concepts he discussed in lectures, whereas the material from the textbooks is more for tutorials.

Professor Sedra's passion for teaching and on the subject is high! Lectures were informative. He does record his lectures, but he does use pictures in class to demonstrates his point. He does not force his opinion on certain topics on his students and is open to all ideas. He cares about everyone in his class. However a high mark is hard to obtain.

Really helpful and really good lecturer. Can be a bit dry at times, but is generally really interesting and provides an interesting perspective on middle eastern history. I think he focused a bit too much on Egypt (because that's his area of speciality), however he does cover other countries in the readings.

My gpa regrets taking this class. All my essays were well written and thought out yet I received grades more appropriate for if I have only written an introduction. WAY to hard a marker for an intro class. PLUS the TA's for this class (mine is particular) were useless!!
Hard marker, cannot attain a good grade in class. Definitely not a GPA booster.
Great lectures. Hard marker.
Excellent lcturing style. Very thoughtful. highly recommended.

He is a very good lecturer and knows what he is talking about. But his lectures are often a repeat of the text book. Expect lots of reading, but he makes class very interesting.Marks hard, good grades are attainable for good writers.

Great prof! He really knows his stuff! His marking scheme is fair...reading the textbook and source book is quite important. He shows a lot of interest and makes learning history really fun! Great class to take!

Great professor. Offers his help and genuinely means it. Lectures can be a bit fast-paced and slides aren't given on WebCT, so you've got to pay attention. Tested mostly on lecture material, though, so although textbook reading is useful for tutorials, not important for exams. Very clear about what he's looking for on exams. Overall, great prof.
Definitely one of the best history profs at SFU.

First of all, Dr. Sedra is a good professor. He speaks in very academic English (for the most part) and it can therefore be a bit tough to stay attentive, but the lecture material is very interesting and he is obviously extremely interested in it. The tutorials and the TA were great. The marking scheme was definitely fair. Worth taking the class!!!
Definitely not a class to take in your first semester of university. Difficult, but interesting. Lectures didn't always mesh with readings.
Takes himself quite seriously, but a good dude nonetheless.  Tough marker though.

Professor Sedra is an awesome lecturer. He speaks with enthusiasm and it really shows he loves Middle Eastern History. However, I found the course to be a little over my head.. The names and terms were sometimes confusing, also, the primary source textbook is very hard to read.

He's a great lecturer and brings fun into the lectures, making you want to actually listen. The only downfall is that he talks too much/too quick and you can't catch everything he says (he doesn't use slides).

This guy actually makes history interesting.  The test and essay aren't a breeze, but I haven't regretted taking the course.  Although he records his lectures, I still keep coming to them because of the excitement he puts into them.  And I liked how he asked everyone to introduce themselves during office hrs early in the term.  Good prof.

The only prof in the history dept who would actually read through an entire draft of a paper with me.  Went out of his way to help, even though he could have ditched me with one of the TAs.  Passionate about the material AND about seeing students understand it.  Too bad there aren't more like him who actually care about what they're teaching.

To the person who made the comment below: it's not highschool anymore! Get used to working hard. Paul Sedra is the best professor that I've had in the History department. The readings he selects are relevant and informative. Go to his office hours, he will help you select research material for your term paper! Awesome prof.

While he has a lot of enthusiasm for what he is teaching, he is an awful professor, the worst I've had. Seems to go out of his way to make things as hard for students as possible: no notes, just expects you to write everything he says in lecture and get things from the excessive amount of readings you have to do each weak. Awful course.
Great Prof! Energetic, humorous, and very intelligent.

Very interesting class, he obviously loves the subject but the marking and tests are very hard, beware. If you want a good grade, keep up to date on all the readings ( there's alot) and memorize as much as you can for the midterm and final.

I've never had a teacher who so truly seemed to care about what he taught, and what's more, who truly wanted to see his students care about it as much as he.  His joyous, bubbly nature reminded me of an excited child who was explaining his favourite toy; this aspect of the tutorials made them incredibly enjoyable., by far.  Great first year teacher
Sedra is a truly excellent professor. He's friendly, intelligent, and he teaches a nicely balanced class.

Sedra is a very good lecturer. The Film series he introduced was great, though I understand that due to its time, some couldn't attend. If you go to class, read the book, it won't be hard to get a B/C. To get an A, though, you'll need to suck up to the TA big time as it is a huge class 150+.

Sedra is so excited about the material he actual chuckles to himself!  He is really fun to listen to and is very helpful.  There is a actually a "cult of sedra" which practically worships him... I guess his enthusiasm is contagious!  BEWARE though, he is a HARD marker!!!!  Talk to him during office hours if you get the chance!
Awesome professor, extreme interest in subject. He introduced a film series this semester that's actually quite interesting once you get oer how late it occurs.

Paul is nice and really interested in Middle Eastern history but his teaching style can be somewhat ineffective and boring. He asks very specific questions & continues trying to drag it out of students even when it is clear no one knows the answer. Very helpful with assignments if you go and see him in his office hours. Overall a good prof.

good knowledge..interesting lectures but a bit of hard marker..u should have very good writing skills if u gonna get his class and if no TA is marking ur paper..too hard on marking especially for 1st year students..other than that..he is very friendly and helpful..

Excellent teacher, excellent course.  He managed to pack a huge amount of material into one semester.  And I like his style: he speaks well, tries to keep the audience entertained.  Kept the class well informed by e-mail.  Assignments a bit tougher than I had expected, but his office hours were great and he always responded within hours to e-mail.

I enjoyed this class a lot.  The prof has an amazing level of enthusiasm which spread among most of the people in my tutorial.  His lectures were, for the most part, lively and challenging.  He was particularly helpful in offering his time for essay help.  I would certainly take future classes with this prof.

I waited 5 semesters to take this class, only to be stuck with sleepy Sedra.  His lectures were boring, disjointed, and incredibly hard to follow with "ok" being spoken every other word.  Lecturing past the allotted class time and then asking the class if they have questions is a definite no no.

Not the best prof for a first year class.  He focuses on various historians rather than the events which can be a little dry and over the heads of first years.  He frequently went over the time limit and wasted class time by asking if anyone had any questions, most of which could be covered in tutorials.  If you can, wait until someone else teaches

He is a great professor and he is always avaliable for help. His marking is very fair and his tests are based on both the lectures and readings. If you attend all his lectures and seek help, you will do well in his class.
One of the best lecturers I've had at SFU, but you're stuck if you don't show up to class. If he'd put his lectures or notes online, this class would have been perfect.

What are you talking about?  The guy tries to give us more than one point of view about history, so he focuses on specific thinkers.  His expectations are high, but that's great if you're into the material.  I like his enthusiasm.  Compared to other profs in the department, he's fantatstic!

I was very excited to take this class. And it turned out to be a joke. This prof is not clear at all. His lectures are very weird for a history class, focusing on specific thinkers rather than the broad focus I expect in a 1st yr history. The topic of our paper was very hard, but it ended up being the topic of lecture on the day it was due!

He's a great professor, and he's very passionate about the Middle East and it shows through his lectures. He's top-notch in clairity, interest, and I like how he some-times leaves a few minutes to answer questions asked by the students. He is a funny guy, and I just wish he put his notes on powerpoint. But, overall, he's good.
A really top-notch lecturer.  Clearly cares a lot about teaching.

No powerpoint, so you have to stay awake and take lots of notes. Relatively hard marker. Paul relates to the class well, walks around, tries to include everyone (which is hard in a big lecture hall!) Overall he's a good teacher, interested in what he's teaching... and he's also a very happy man... with an extremely hearty laugh!!
No Comments
